Award.AwardTitle: SI2-SSE: A Next-Generation Open-Source Computational Fluid Dynamic Code for Polydisperse Multiphase Flows in Science and Engineering

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Many processes for the production of drugs, fuels and plastic materials, as well as energy from coal or biomasses, involve multiphase flows, which are composed by a combination of a fluid, either liquid or gas, and particles, droplets or bubbles. This type of flow is also naturally present in the environment. Examples are the formation of a mixture of air and solid particles due to volcanic eruptions, and particles of sand and other materials transported by the wind. Scientists and engineers use software to study how these flows behave in order to improve the yield of industrial processes, reduce their environmental impact, and energy consumption. The computer programs used to perform these studies solve complex mathematical problems, and require powerful computers to be able to obtain the results in a useful time. This project focuses on developing the next generation of computer software for the simulation of multiphase flows, enabling it to use the latest generation of computers which combine traditional and graphical processors for improved performance. This software will be released to the public and will enable, scientists and engineers from different research areas to tackle real-world problems by taking advantage of the latest developments in multiphase flow science, combined with the benefit of being able to use the software on powerful computer infrastructures. Students and educators will be able to use the software and learn about multiphase flows through the examples and the documentation that will be provided.

The objectives of the project will be achieved by first developing computational models to describe turbulent flows in the framework of quadrature-based moment methods, an efficient and accurate approach to describe this type of flows. These computational models will then be implemented, together with appropriate numerical methods that will ensure the accuracy of the computational codes, in the open-source framework OpenFOAM. Three representative problems of typical multiphase flows will be considered: a population balance equation for particles with negligible inertia, such as in the formation of nanoparticles in a fluid flow; the description of gas-liquid flows, where the bubble inertia is small but not zero; and the most complex case of gas-solid flows, where particle inertia is large. The possibility of using graphical processing units will be added to the OpenFOAM framework, to enable it to run on hybrid computational systems involving traditional processors and graphical processing units. The source code and its documentation will be made available to the public at an early stage of their development, under the GNU GPL 3 license, in order to disseminate the results of the research and gather feedback. Detailed code documentation, verification and validation cases, and tutorials will also be created to favor external contributions to the software.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main outcome of the project is an open-source implementation of quadrature-based moment methods for the numerical simulation of multiphase flows. These flows are constituted by a disperse phase made of particles, bubbles or droplets in a carrier fluid. The methods implemented as part of this project allow these flows to be simulated numerically in large-scale systems of interest to engineers (e.g. chemical reactors, exhaust treatment devices and facilities, filters) and scientists (e.g. aerosols, atmospheric flows, pollutant dispersion) at reasonable computational cost.

A computational framework, OpenQBMM, based on the open-source toolbox for computational fluid dynamics OpenFOAM was developed. The framework is composed by a core library and several applications that address particular problems involving multiphase flows. Specifically, the library contains the implementation of the base algorithms required by quadrature-based moment methods. These include numerical methods to integrate the advection term of moments of a distribution and the source terms that appear in the evolution equations for the moments. Such numerical methods ensure that moments of the distribution are preserved, guaranteeing the robustness of the numerical procedure.

Specific physical models to describe the evolution of particle size due to phenomena such as aggregation and breakage of small particles (e.g. nanoparticles used in the pharmaceutical industry to carry medications), whose inertia is negligible were implemented. These models were tested against data taken from the literature and the considered test cases are provided as part of the OpenQBMM framework.

Computational models for gas-liquid systems where bubbles are present due to the injection or formation of gas or vapor into a liquid (e.g. bubble columns, stirred tank reactors, propulsion of ships) were also developed and implemented. These models are more complex than those used for small particles with negligible inertia (nanoparticles) because bubbles have more inertia and do not exactly adapt to the changes of the velocity field of the fluid phase. Additionally, bubbles can have different sizes. They can coalesce and break, and bubbles with different sizes can move with different velocities. A computational model capable of describing these effects was implemented and successfully tested against several experimental data sets from the literature.

Four Ph.D. students and two M.S. students were supported by the project. Three of the four Ph.D. students and both the M.S. students have successfully graduated. All the Ph.D. students and one of the graduate students are currently employed. The other M.S. student is continuing his studies.

Six peer-reviewerd journal publications in relevant journals to the commuity were produced. Results obtained during the project were disseminated at two peer-reviewed conferences and at nine other conferences. Several lectures and short courses were delivered to disseminate the results of the project to relevant audiences in industry and academia.

The source code of the OpenQBMM project was released under the GNU General Public License 3, together with tutorials and test cases.
